The `normalDistrib` function is part of a collection of utility functions designed for probabilistic and statistical operations. It generates random numbers within a specified range [a, b] using a Gaussian distribution, ensuring that results are confined within the given bounds through iterative resampling if necessary. This function complements other utilities in the document by providing a method to produce normally distributed values while leveraging Python's standard `random` module for underlying randomness generation.

def normalDistrib(a, b, gauss=random.gauss):
    """
    NOTE: assumes a < b

    Returns random number between a and b, using gaussian distribution, with
    mean=avg(a, b), and a standard deviation that fits ~99.7% of the curve
    between a and b.

    For ease of use, outlying results are re-computed until result is in [a, b]
    This should fit the remaining .3% of the curve that lies outside [a, b]
    uniformly onto the curve inside [a, b]

    ------------------------------------------------------------------------
    The 68-95-99.7% Rule
    ====================
    All normal density curves satisfy the following property which is often
      referred to as the Empirical Rule:
    68% of the observations fall within 1 standard deviation of the mean.
    95% of the observations fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean.
    99.7% of the observations fall within 3 standard deviations of the mean.
